t: Psalm 90
Eternal God and Mortal Man
A prayer of Moses, the man of God.
Lord,*pn you have been our refuge in*ln every generation.
Before*ln the mountains were born, before*ln you gave birth to the earth and the world, from*ln eternity to eternity, you are God.
You*pn return mankind to the dust, saying,*ln “Return, descendants of Adam.”
For*ln in your sight a thousand years are*ln like yesterday that passes by, like*ln a few hours of the night.
You*ln end their lives; they sleep. They*ln are like grass that grows in the morning —
in*ln the morning it sprouts and grows; by*ln evening it withers and dries up.
For*pn we are consumed by your anger; we*ln are terrified by your wrath.
You*ln have set our iniquities before you, our*ln secret sins in the light of your presence.
For*ln all our days ebb away under your wrath; we*ln end our years like a sigh.
Our*ln lives last seventy years or,*ln if we are strong, eighty years. Even*ln the best of them are struggle and sorrow; indeed,*ln they pass quickly and we fly away.
Who*ln understands the power of your anger? Your*ln wrath matches the fear that is due you.
Teach*ln us to number our days carefully so*ln that we may develop wisdom in our hearts.
Lord-*spn how long? Turn*ln and have compassion on your servants.
Satisfy*ln us in the morning with your faithful love so*ln that we may shout with joy and be glad all our days.
Make*ln us rejoice for as many days as you have humbled us, for*ln as many years as we have seen adversity.
Let*ln your work be seen by your servants, and*ln your splendor by their children.
Let*ln the favor of the Lord our God be on us; establish*ln for us the work of our hands — establish*ln the work of our hands!
